Award.AwardTitle: The future of ecological engineering: A student-led vision

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will provide student travel fellowships to the 2019 American Ecological Engineering Society (AEES) annual meeting, as well as to provide facilities for a student-oriented poster session and career networking event there. This funding will supplement AEES' ongoing efforts to engage students in the society and the discipline more broadly. The AEES annual meeting is the premier venue for ecological engineers to present new work to their colleagues and garner valuable feedback on their research. It allows researchers to hear about the latest discoveries, trends, and challenges in the field and related disciplines, and make connections that enhance their research programs through interactions with colleagues from different institutions around the country and world. Feedback collected from students supported by travel fellowships will be used to better understand how the discipline is perceived by the next generation of ecological engineers.

The AEES meeting will have approximately 170- 200 attendees; approximately half are expected to be undergraduate or graduate students studying fields related to ecological engineering. To increase the overall diversity at the meeting and within the discipline, student travel fellowships will be awarded to prioritize attendance by under-represented institutions and geographic regions. Through the networking session to be supported through requested funds, students will have the opportunity to interact with faculty and industry professionals working in the field of ecological engineering. Anticipated outcomes of this session include expanding student mentoring/professional networks and exposing them a variety of career pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) provided funding through a conference grant to support AEES? broader efforts to engage students in the society and in the profession of ecological engineering. The funds provided by NSF were used to offset travel costs to the 2019 annual meeting of AEES (held in Asheville, NC) for 39 students ($15,609) and to secure facilities at the conference venue for a student poster and career networking session ($1,650). Students supported by travel grants represented the majority of students in attendance at the conference and included five undergraduate students. Students represented diverse disciplinary and cultural backgrounds and perspectives, including both female and male (23 and 17, respectively) and historically under-represented groups in STEM fields. Students represented 18 different universities, the majority of which were located in the Southeast US (15) but also included students from the Northeast (8), Midwest (9), Northwest (4), and Columbia (3).   

 

Travel awards fostered a high rate of student participation during the conference. While not required as part of the award, 35 of the 39 funded students presented their work in either poster (19) or oral presentation (16) formats. All funded students participated in the student design competition, which entailed creating a video to address the question: What does ecological engineering mean to you? In addition to participating in the conference, many student receiving travel awards through this grant provided feedback to surveys and interviews administered before, during and after the conference as part of AEES? ongoing efforts to better understand the perspectives, goals and needs of students ?growing up? in the discipline of ecological engineering. Key observations from student surveys include:

  • Students tended to favor career paths in the private or industry sectors; however, they also indicated a high interest in careers in the academic/research, governmental, and NGO sectors.
  • Irrespective of career path preferences, students tended to define their professional success broadly to encompass aspects of job performance, personal satisfaction and contributions to their community.
  • To be successful in their chosen career path, students identified opportunities already provided by AEES (attending technical/scientific conferences, membership in professional societies), opportunities toward which AEES is working to strengthen (professional certification, licensure), and opportunities that AEES could consider taking up (mentoring programs).

The findings of these surveys are currently being used by the AEES executive committee and its respective standing committees to ensure student inclusion and success is promoted through the society?s activities.
